Connectivity and Infrastructure: Expand ICT infrastructure and affordable internet access in schools.
Affordability is relative to both the offeror and the buyer. So how would the team ensure that remote and peri-urban areas can afford internet.

From past experiences, urban areas enjoy the most from such initiatives because the peri-urban and remove areas are left to chance and most of them do not receive the necessary continuous support after such initiatives are launched.

Also, there is the need to ensure that the facilities are not used by only the staff but the students. Again, from past experiences I know an institution that would only allow ICT students to use the computer lab about 2 times a term. However, the staff use the internet and computers whenever they wanted.
The collaboration and clear delineation of roles of the content innovators was perfect because they will work closely with the curriculum experts for alignment of contents in the various subjects.
This aspect was done perfectly, but the local content must be developed in a way that it may not discriminate against any ethnic group in Ghana.
The local content must be flexible for teachers to adjust it to their various settings for easy implementation.
In developing local content, a National Repository of Approved Digital Learning Resources must be managed by NaCCA to wipe away the infiltration of the non-approved learning resources online.
There must be the need to develop quality assurance rubrics for evaluating relevance, inclusivity, and cultural appropriateness of local content by NaCCA technical team to valid the rubrics.
The must be strategic motivation drive through an incentivize teachers and EdTech innovators who develop high-quality localized local content through national grants or awards scheme.
To holistically foster the development of local content curriculum, I would recommend the integration of the above points into the policy.

It is a great step, and if effectively implemented, the strategy could transform Ghana’s education landscape and make it more inclusive, efficient, and globally competitive. However, it will require strong leadership, sustained investment, and ongoing stakeholder engagement to realize its full potential.

Interactive digital platforms now make lessons more engaging, while assistive technologies ensure that learners with special needs are not left behind. With data systems offering real-time insights, teachers can better understand student progress and adapt their methods.

These technology should be complemented with industry or career linked curriculum to create a mindset on what the future workforce looks like to boost learners interest and confidence to continue to explore more into other areas of technological interest.

For Ghana, the path ahead lies in the adoption of a hybrid innovation, one that combines the promise of cutting-edge technology with the practicality of offline access. It means equipping schools with both digital and non-digital tools that foster creativity, inclusivity, and critical thinking skilss. As Ghana strives it way to a digital journey toward a digitally empowered education system, success will depend not only on what technologies are introduced, but on how well they reach every learner, regardless of whereevr they are coming from.
